citation.article-title: Bartonella rattaustraliani sp. nov., Bartonella queenslandensis sp. nov. and Bartonella coopersplainsensis sp. nov., identified in Australian rats
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Bartonella coopersplainsensis sp. nov.

Bartonella coopersplainsensis (coo.pers.plain.sen′sis. N.L. fem. adj. coopersplainsensis pertaining to Coopers Plains, Queensland, the name of the area where the rat was trapped from which the type strain was isolated).
The single known isolate assigned to this species exhibits all of the characteristics of the genus (Birtles et al., 1995).
Good growth is observed on Columbia agar with 5 % sheep blood in a 5 % CO2 atmosphere at 37 °C, where colonies appear small, white, smooth and irregular (about 0.5 mm in diameter) after 20 days.
Electron microscope examination reveals small bacilli without flagella, approximately 1–2 μm long by 0.5 μm wide.
Susceptible to aminoglycosides, macrolides, doxycycline and rifampicin; resistant to vancomycin, and imipenem is more effective against the type strain.
Differentiated genetically from other Bartonella species on the basis of sequences of the 16S rRNA, ftsZ, gltA and rpoB genes and the ITS region.
The type strain is AUST/NH20T (=CIP 109064T =CCUG 52174T =CSUR B619T), isolated from blood of a wild rat of the species Rattus leucopus.
